com.percussion.cms.objectstore
Class PSRelationshipProcessorProxy

java.lang.Object
  com.percussion.cms.objectstore.PSProcessorProxy
      com.percussion.cms.objectstore.PSRelationshipProcessorProxy
All Implemented Interfaces:
IPSRelationshipProcessor
public class PSRelationshipProcessorProxy
extends PSProcessorProxy
implements IPSRelationshipProcessor

This class presents the interfaces supported by the processor classes, but doesn't actually perform any work. It has a configuration file that is read to find the appropriate processor g178iven a component type. That processor is instantiated and is used to perform the heavy lifting. Once the processor type is known, the config is searched for associated properties for the supplied component and procesor. These properties are made available to the real processor. The default processors support web services and direct server access both locally and remotely.

See the config schema, sys_CmsProcessorConfig.xsd for details on the format of the configuration file.

To provide an idea of how it will work, let's look at what happens when an operation is performed on a remote client using web services, say creating a new instance of some type.

  1. A new instance of the object would be created locally using the standard technique (e.g., new PSFolder("foo")).
  2. The object would be manipulated until it reached the desired state.
  3. The object would then be passed to the save method of this class.
  4. The proxy would look up the real processor and pass it the properties from the config file, which would include the name of the web service to use.
  5. The real processor would call toXml on the component and pass this element as the document when making the web service request. This request would be received by the web services handler at the server.
  6. The handler would re-create the original object, passing the supplied xml to the component's fromXml method.
  7. This object would then be passed to the local proxy processor's save method.
  8. The local proxy would look up the real processor and pass the config information. By default this processor will generate a new key and call toDbXml on the component and pass the generated fragment to the resource defined in the processor's config
  9. After this is successful, setPersisted is called on the component.
  10. Success is returned to the web service caller.
  11. The WS processor will call setPersisted on the remote object.
When the methods of a processor are called, a component type must be supplied (or it is obtained from the supplied component). In general, this should be the base name of the component (but for the relationship processor methods, it is an arbitrary name, usually based on the type of relationship being processed). This name is used to find the 'real' processor class name and a set of properties appropriate for this type of component. Most components will use the generic processor, which performs an internal request to a resource as described above.

Version:
1.0
Author:
Paul Howard

Method Detail

add

public void add(String componentType,
                String relationshipType,
                List children,
                PSKey targetParent)
         throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSRelationshipProcessor
Creates a new relationship between the supplied parent and each supplied child of the type specified by relationshipType and stores it in the database.

The process is transaction safe, meaning it either completes successfully, or the database is unchanged.

Specified by:
add in interface IPSRelationshipProcessor
Parameters:
componentType - One of the supported names for relationship processing. Never null or empty.
relationshipType - The internal name of the relationship type you wish to create. May not be empty or null. The name is case-insensitive.
children - Each entry must be a valid PSLocator, which is a key that references an existing object in the database. Never null . If empty, this method returns immediately without exception.
targetParent - A valid key referencing the object that will own the generated relationships. A valid key is one that references an existing object in the database. Never null. If the type of the children is not supported by the target parent, an exception is thrown.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If the processor for the supplied type is not found or cannot be instantiated, or any problems occur while adding the relationship(s).

move

public void move(String relationshipType,
                 PSKey sourceParent,
                 List children,
                 PSKey targetParent)
          throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSRelationshipProcessor
Changes the parent of each relationship to the supplied children from the source parent to the target parent.

The process is transaction safe, meaning it either completes successfully, or the database is unchanged.

Specified by:
move in interface IPSRelationshipProcessor
Parameters:
relationshipType - A releationship type name known to the system, may be null or empty in which case all relationship irrespective of the relationship type will be moved. Otherwise only the relationships of this type will be considered for moving.
sourceParent - A valid key that references the current owner of the relationships to all the supplied children. A valid key is one that references an existing object of the correct type in the database. Never null.
children - Each entry must be a valid PSLocator, which is a key that references an existing object in the database. Never null. If empty, this method returns immediately without exception. If the type of the children are not supported by the target parent, an exception is thrown.
targetParent - A valid key referencing the object that will own the relationships after the move. A valid key is one that references an existing object in the database. Never null.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If the processor for the supplied type is not found or cannot be instantiated, or any problems occur while moving the relationship(s).

copy

public void copy(String relationshipType,
                 List children,
                 PSKey targetParent)
          throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSRelationshipProcessor
Creates a new relationship of specified relationship type for each child linking the child to the target parent. Whether the child is cloned is dependent on the effects associated with the relationship type.

The process is not transaction safe. If the process fails, the caller should requery the target parent to determine which relationships were actually created.

Specified by:
copy in interface IPSRelationshipProcessor
Parameters:
relationshipType - Must be one of the relationship types configured in the system.
children - Each entry must be a valid PSKey, which is a key that references an existing object in the database. Never null . If empty, this method returns immediately without exception. If the type of the children is not supported by the target parent, an exception is thrown.
targetParent - A valid key referencing the object that will own the newly created relationships. A valid key is one that references an existing object in the database. Never null.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If any problems occur while copying the relationship(s).

delete

public void delete(String relationshipType,
                   PSKey sourceParent,
                   List children)
            throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSRelationshipProcessor
Permanently removes the relationship type specified between each child and the source parent. Provide null for relationship type and dependents to delete all relationships for the supplied owner. Whether the child is deleted is dependent on the effects associated with the relationship type being removed.

The process is not transaction safe. If the process fails, the caller should requery the source parent to determine which relationships were actually removed.

Specified by:
delete in interface IPSRelationshipProcessor
Parameters:
relationshipType - the relationship type to delete, may be null but not empty, in which case the dependents of all relationship types will be deleted. An exception is thrown if the requested type was not found in the relationship configuration.
sourceParent - A valid key that references the current owner of the relationships to all the supplied children. A valid key is one that references an existing object in the database. Never null.
children - Each entry must be a non-null PSLocator. If the key does not reference a child of the supplied parent, it is skipped. Never null. If empty, this method returns immediately without exception.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If the suppied relationship type (if supplied) is not found or cannot be instantiated, or any problems occur while removing the relationship(s).

getRelationships

public PSRelationshipSet getRelationships(String relationshipType,
                                          PSLocator locator,
                                          boolean owner)
                                   throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSRelationshipProcessor
Catalogs all relationships for a given object, or possibly only those relationships that have a given name.

Specified by:
getRelationships in interface IPSRelationshipProcessor
Parameters:
relationshipType - The internal name or category of the relationship type you wish to limit your request to. If empty or null , all types are returned. The name is case-insensitive. Relationship types are checked first, then categories.
locator - The unique identifier for the object for which you want the relationships. Never null. If no revision is supplied, all relationships are returned, otherwise only those relationships for the requested revision, plus all relationships that don't use revisions are returned.
owner - If true, relationships which are owned by the object are returned, otherwise relationships for which the requested object is a dependent are returned.
Returns:
A valid array of 0 or more relationship objects, in no particular order.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If any problems occur trying to get the relationships, such as a db failure.

getSummaryByPath

public PSComponentSummary getSummaryByPath(String componentType,
                                           String path,
                                           String relationshipTypeName)
                                    throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSRelationshipProcessor
Locate the object and get the component summary given fully qualified path and relationship type name. A full qualified path has following syntax.

/root/child_1/child_2/child_3/../../child_n

In this root, child_1, child_2 etc are the sys_title fields of the objects (Content Item or Folder). The method makes sure the root object with sys_title field value 'root' indeed is a root, i.e. ha no parent or owner. The component summary returned will refer to the right most object (child_n) in the above path. Any two consecutive objects in the path are related by the supplied relationship type.

Specified by:
getSummaryByPath in interface IPSRelationshipProcessor
Parameters:
componentType - The value returned by the IPSDbComponent.getComponentType() method of the component being processed. Never empty or null. If the name is not found in the config, an exception is thrown.
path - fully qualified relationship path as explained above, must not be null or empty.
relationshipTypeName - name of the relationship that any two consecutive objects related by, Must be one of the relationship types known to the system (which is configured in the workbench).
Returns:
Component summary for the leaf object (referred by child_n above) in the path, can benull if there is no such relationship path exists in the system.
Throws:
PSCmsException

getRelationshipOwnerPaths

public String[] getRelationshipOwnerPaths(String componentType,
                                          PSLocator locator,
                                          String relationshipTypeName)
                                   throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSRelationshipProcessor
Get the relationship owner paths for a given item. The relationship owner path is generated the following way:
  1. Get the owner(s) of the current item and record the sys_title field of this item
  2. For each owner found walk to its parent in a recursive way until there is no owner found
  3. Generate the path for every for every route recursed in the syntax:

    sys_title_owner1/sys_title_owner2/.../sys_title_owner_last

Note that the paths generated could be multidimensional when an item in the path has more than one owner. However, this implementation is suitable ONLY folder relationship or a relationship that allows only one parent for an object. The exception is that the first object can have multiple parents and then parents have only one parent each. This means the use case of an item that exists in multiple folders is very well covered by this implementation since one folder can exist in only one folder.

Specified by:
getRelationshipOwnerPaths in interface IPSRelationshipProcessor
Parameters:
componentType - The value returned by the IPSDbComponent.getComponentType() method of the component being processed. Never empty or null. If the name is not found in the config, an exception is thrown.
locator - Loctaor of the item for which the owner paths are to be generated, must not be null.
relationshipTypeName - name of the relationship that any two consecutive objects related by, Must be one of the relationship types known to the system (which is configured in the workbench).
Returns:
An array of paths per one recursive route explained above. Never null. Will be empty if the object with supplied locator has no owner by the relationship supplied.
Throws:
PSCmsException - if path generation fails for any reason.

isDescendent

public boolean isDescendent(String componentType,
                            PSLocator parent,
                            PSLocator child,
                            String relationshipTypeName)
                     throws PSCmsException
Description copied from interface: IPSRelationshipProcessor
Method to test if a given object is a descendent of specified parent object. The test succeeds if the parent specified matches with any object between the object above the child and the root in the ancestor tree, which means the parent is an immediate parent or a grand parent via the relationship type supplied.

This method assumes that the an object will never have more than one parent and dependent is revision insensitive, which means this is NOT applicable to the relationship type categories that allow multiple parents for an item/object, e.g. PSRelationshipConfig.CATEGORY_ACTIVE_ASSEMBLY.

Specified by:
isDescendent in interface IPSRelationshipProcessor
Parameters:
componentType - The value returned by the IPSDbComponent.getComponentType() method of the component being processed. Never empty or null. If the name is not found in the config, an exception is thrown.
parent - Locator of the parent object, must not be null.
child - Locator of the child object, must not be null.
relationshipTypeName - name of the relationship between the two objects, must not be null or empty.
Returns:
true if parent is related to child via the relationshipTypeName and child is indeed descendent of parent, false otherwise.
Throws:
PSCmsException - if the check could not be performed for any reason.

Throws:
PSCmsException - PSCmsException If the processor for the supplied type is not found or cannot be instantiated, or any problems occur.
